user_query: How truthful is the statement that "Malaria has a low vectorial capacity."? Present a series of factual points about the statement.

Malaria transmission occurs when an infected female Anopheles mosquito bites a human host and inoculates sporozoites into the bloodstream. The sporozoites travel to the liver, where they infect hepatocytes and mature into schizonts. After a period of asexual replication, the schizonts release merozoites, which infect erythrocytes and cause disease symptoms.
Malaria vectorial capacity is defined as the number of mosquito bites required to produce one infectious bite. The vectorial capacity of malaria is low, meaning that a small number of mosquito bites can lead to infection. In fact, just one infectious mosquito bite can result in a malaria infection.
Malaria is a serious global health problem, with an estimated 200 million cases and 500,000 deaths each year. The vast majority of cases occur in Africa, where children under the age of 5 are the most vulnerable. Malaria transmission is a complex process, and the vectorial capacity of the disease is just one factor that contributes to its spread.
